Name: Michael Lee
Intro: Hi all! I'm Michael, an energy nerd and CEO/co-founder of Evolve Energy.  I've been in the renewables industry for the past 10 years and have seen this really interesting progression in wholesale energy markets where times of the day when renewables are abundant are also the lowest cost times of the day.  So at Evolve, we sell electricity at this wholesale power rate in deregulated markets to residential customers so they can save money AND truly decarbonize their footprint because they are implicitly shifting their usage to times when renewables are abundant and shedding load when it's coal and gas on the margin.  We do some fun stuff with IOT and ML to automate usage timing, which also translates to an interesting product for regulated markets/utilities.  This recent VentureBeat article describes it a bit more and happy to chat with anyone looking to understand this industry! (we're hiring soon!) https://venturebeat.com/2019/11/05/evolve-energy-uses-machine-learning-and-analytics-to-save-renewable-energy-customers-money/

We published an index last fall of technology developers and are now in the midst of developing an index of relevant capital providers. We were part of a lonely and niche group of believers and evangelists for much of the 2010s, but that's dramatically changed for the better in recent years. 
I've also got a small startup portfolio, either through advisory board participation or a few small checks. I spend about half my time working closely with HEVO, a wireless EV charging startup I'm excited about. Wires create a lot of problems for a variety of stakeholders and wireless charging addresses those challenges.  
I live in Brooklyn with my wife, 3-year-old son, and 3-month-old daughter. I only started listening to the pod in the last few weeks, but I enjoyed the conversation with Albert Wenger. Name: Chad Frischmann
Intro:
My name is Chad Frischmann, and I am one of the originators of Project Drawdown with Paul Hawken and Amanda Ravenhill, as well as a Co-Author of the book Drawdown: the most comprehensive plan ever proposed to reverse global warming. Since we started in 2014, and still to this day, I am the head of research and technology development, as well as the lead of the Drawdown Global Research Collaborative and other partnerships.
I designed our research methodology and models that can evaluate the potential of nearly any technology or practice contribute to achieving Drawdown (the point in time when we stop and begin to reverse global warming). Over the years, I led our team of over 80 research fellows from around the to collect data on the most viable climate solutions to input into our model sand determine if Drawdown is possible.
Good news: it is!!  Please check out our website at www.drawdown.org or pick up the book at your local bookstore to learn more.
But also be prepared: I am just wrapping up the latest set of results for our Drawdown 2020 Review coming out very soon (until the printers let us know, I'll keep the date under wraps, but I can say that Saturday is my final model run :wink:. Most of the assessments and models were updated over the last year, and the results and rankings have changed. Not enough for you to not go buy the book though (seriously, the book is worth it).
What I can offer: anything and everything related to Drawdown or Regeneration. If you want to hear a talk for your community (big or small), feel free to reach out. My current talk is Drawdown to Regeneration: creating the Future We Want today.
What I need: We are in the process to developing an online knowledge platform for solutions built around the Drawdown Global Research Collaborative. Python software 70% complete (I need more coders!), Data Repository being developed (I need Commoners!), Dynamic User Portals being conceived (I need designers, facilitators and volunteer stakeholders!), Collaborative being launched (I need researchers and data collectors!), and funders are being sought (I need funding!!).
Reach out anytime on here or at chad@drawdown.org.

Name: DanielErnst
Intro:
Hello MCJ travelers
I am Daniel Ernst a technology, media & telecom investor / analyst on a simultaneous climate and career transition journey. ( as in Im looking for a job, preferably a career, and a forever home)

Early in my career I built spectrum auction models, and I continued to cover the industry’s evolution as mobile overtook landline, and as smartphones surpassed personal computers. Applying that structural lens to the broader economy, I see an accelerating shift toward sustainability. As monumental as technology-driven change has been, I believe the transition to a low carbon economy will be significantly more disruptive. ( disrupt or we die )
I believe my experience identifying technology driven secular shifts is directly applicable to understanding the circular economy transition.
Beyond core renewable technology, I believe innovations from ai to iot hold great promise to improve efficiency in agriculture, buildings, manufacturing and logistics.
Despite the tremendous uptake of funds embracing ESG, signing commitments like the PRI and Climate Action 100, most of those portfolios are uninspiring and the earth is still warming. ( striking parallels to funds that largely ignored AAPL AMZN ATVI CRM NFLX until the disruption they wrought was better understood)
Ive been to several sustainable investing conferences, taken courses, read a ton, listened to (almost) every MCJ episode and completed the first level of SASB - Sustainable Accounting Standards Board certification.
Thanks for reading this far, looking forward to what’s next

Intro:

I spent about 8 months learning about it and talking to knowledgeable people, confirming that there was a major  gap, and that it wasn't a completely impossible problem.
In November I quit my job, packed up my San Francisco apartment and moved to Cambodia, where I'm trying to get something off the ground. Ultimately I think that the solution to refrigerant management (especially end-of-life recovery, but also leakage) will involve positive financial incentives relying on digital technology to verify additionality. I don't think anyone knows what that verification will entail, but my hypothesis is that
a) it's possible
b) the best way to figure it out is to build it as an internal system for a company that's actually operating on the ground.
So that's the plan! This is my first time starting something completely from scratch, though I've been an early employee a few times. Name: Paul Yacoubian
Intro:
I'm a Partner at the ESO Venture Funds and also an angel investor.
I started my climate journey after smelling the smoke of the Paradise fires while on a trip to SF. I found out that wildfire seasons were getting increasingly hot and dry and that California had already seen the 3 degree jump in temperatures!
I called Google's carbon team to see if I could throw down some money to buy carbon credits with them and they said no. I tried buying some landfill gas credits through Element Markets in Houston but they tried selling me credits that I later found out were for projects that shut down 10 years ago. I looked into the owner and found out that he was one of the masterminds of the fraud at Enron. I looked into Terrapass and learned that the owner lives in a 40k square foot house. I decided that we needed a high trust carbon offset subscription as a service aka Netflix for Saving the Planet.
I pitched 100 of my friends and family members and got 30+ signups. Then Project Wren launched on TechCrunch this past summer and it was exactly what I wanted to build. I shut down my project and invested in their company instead. That's how I met Jason.
The 2nd biggest problem other than finding good projects was figuring out how to help people live lower carbon lifestyles. As it turns out, quarantine living is the lowest carbon lifestyle you can possibly have. No driving, no flying, just remote work and hanging out with your family in the backyard. I'm now working with a few designers and hardware specialists on building out the infrastructure needed to take existing homes off the grid, totally eliminating a major portion of your carbon footprint in the process.
I think our best chance to alter consumer behavior is to capitalize on the pandemic quarantines of the next 12-24 months and see how much will stick.
I have started a slack channel today for people who are interested in joining a pandemic action response team. Part of this team will be focused on coordinating the manufacture of these low carbon systems. DM for an invite or if you'd like to chat!

Intro:
Hi everyone, I’m Chris, co-founder/CEO at Plausible Labs (https://twitter.com/plausiblelabs), a worker-owned software cooperative based in San Francisco, which is also where I live with my wife and two kids.  Plausible has been around for more than a decade; we’ve worked with a range of clients (mostly startups) while also building things of our own (mobile/desktop apps + low-level tooling/libraries).  Prior to Plausible, I spent 10 years at Sun Microsystems modernizing Java’s graphics+UI stacks.
These past few years, I’ve grown dissatisfied with the nature of our work, too often getting involved with projects that, while not entirely without merit, don’t seem to do much good in the Big Picture.  I’ve been a casual observer of the climate space for a long time, but it wasn’t until early 2019 that it finally clicked that I could orient my career to helping somehow in the fight against climate change.  (Talks with my young kids, and frequent scoldings from Greta, played no small part in that mental shift.)
I’ve spent the last few months learning as much as I can about the climate landscape.  And at Plausible, I’ve been working to shed extraneous projects so that we can focus on more useful work.  We’re now committed to taking on new consulting work only with companies whose primary mission is in fighting climate change.  I’m hoping Plausible can gain trust/reputation within this community with our solid engineering work, while also serving as a landing/launching pad for similarly-minded software folks who want to shift their careers in this direction.

We’re building the first sustainable cooking app, to help individuals understand and reduce their dietary carbon footprint + figure out what to eat on a warming planet. We’re in open beta so you can already use the app on iOS: https://testflight.apple.com/join/2WNNrQ8j
Feedback is more than welcome. We make all recipes, photography and code in-house.
We calculate the carbon footprint of each recipe (for each month of the year as it varies drastically with seasonality), in your region (currently covering US and France), and suggest the ones that have the smallest footprint. One meal may seem like a drop in the ocean, but it quickly adds up, agriculture and what we eat making up to 27% of GHG emissions (source: https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/agriculture/our-insights/agriculture-plays-a-critical-role-in-limiting-the-impact-of-climate-change).
“Fun” fact: an out-of-season ingredient has a carbon footprint that’s 5 times bigger on average than a seasonal one. I’m never buying eggplant in December anymore :man-shrugging: .
